distinguishing_features: Dark body coloration with lighter bands
Lighter ventral scales visible on the underside of the hood
Distinct head shape typical of Naja species
Presence of a single, somewhat indistinct ocellus (monocle) pattern on the hood

similar_candidates.why_not: Typically exhibits a clearer 'spectacle' pattern (two ocelli connected by a bar) on the hood, which is not distinctly visible here.
Generally larger, has a different head profile, and typically lacks a distinct hood pattern like a monocle or spectacle, though can have chevron markings.

conservation.protected_status: CITES Appendix II, Wildlife Protection Act, 1972, Schedule II (India)

danger_profile.threat_to_humans: Highly dangerous, capable of delivering a potent venomous bite that can cause severe envenomation, leading to paralysis, tissue damage, and death if untreated.
danger_profile.evidence: Known highly venomous species, image shows an alert cobra in a defensive posture.

health_indicators.condition: Appears alert and healthy based on the visual evidence in the image.

habitat_context.environment: Dry, open ground with sparse vegetation, possibly near human habitation or agricultural land.

evidence: Threat description 'maar ho gaya' (it was killed/died) indicates the snake was likely killed, which is illegal for a protected species.
suspicious_activity: Killing of a protected and vulnerable snake species.

risk_assessment.ai-report: A vulnerable Monocled Cobra has reportedly been killed due to habitat loss, indicating severe human-wildlife conflict and potential illegal activity requiring urgent intervention.
